Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI will investigate the topology of random cell complexes and the geometry of random groups. Phase transitions are one important theme -- vanishing thresholds for homology or homotopy groups as some parameter varies, for example. Also of interest are more geometric notions, such as isoperimetric inequalities and hyperbolicity. Random cell complexes provide high-dimensional analogues of expander graphs, a subject that has been a very active lately, with connections to random matrix theory. The probabilistic method provides a powerful and general framework for generating objects with extremal geometric properties, and progress in this area will lead to intriguing new examples and counterexamples in topological combinatorics and geometric group theory.

This research draws on several areas of mathematics to study subtle qualitative features of randomly generated shapes. These interactions are of intrinsic interest within mathematics itself, and the work is also being done with a eye towards practical applications in the emerging area of topological data analysis. The educational activities supported by the grant will be naturally integrated with the research, and the PI will mentor graduate and undergraduate researchers working on projects related to the grant. The PI will continue to be involved with various outreach activities: Colorado Math Olympiad, Canada/USA Mathcamp, math circles, undergraduate math clubs, and problem solving seminars.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project was to study random topological spaces. The study of random shapes is natural and important within mathematics itself. For example, the probabilistic method provides a framework for novel existence proofs when we are short on constructive methods. Stochastic topology also has a number of scientific applications. For example, the grain structure of a metallic material seems like some kind of random cell complex. Finally, stochastic topology is important for the emerging field of topological data analysis. Understanding topological invariants connected to a random set of points is an important null hypothesis to compare with the invariants extracted from a point cloud.

Intellectual Merit. The PI made headway on a number of fronts proposed in this project.

In terms of applications within mathematics, one of the most exciting discoveries was finding torsion in homology of random simplicial complexes. Homology measures the (possibly high-dimensional) "holes" in a topological space, and the torsion somehow measures the "twistedness" of those holes. It has been an open problem since the beginning of the study of random simplicial complexes whethere there is ever any torsion in homology. In a paper by Kahle, Lutz, Newman, and Parsons which appeared in Experimental Mathematics, we gave strong experimental evidence that torsion exists for a short burst in the process. Moreover, we can make very precise predictions about where this torsion burst appears, how large it is, and its structure of the limiting distribution of the torsion over various prime numbers. This paper will motivate new directions in this area over the next few years. Somewhat inspired by this work, the PI's PhD student Newman proved the existence of simplicial complex with prescribed torsion in homology, again applying the probabilistic method.

Another major success of this project was in a breakthrough result on the "persistent homology" of random geometric complexes. This is a paper by Bobrowski, Kahle, and Skraba, which appeared in Annals of Applied Probability. Take n random points in d-dimensional Euclidean space, and ask: how large is the largest hole? We measure the size of the largest hole topologically with persistent homology, and in a scale-invariant way, and the results are sharp up to a constant factor. In topological inference, one often considers "long bars" in the persistence barcode to represent signal, and "short bars" to represent noise, and this is the strongest rigorous result to date on separating signal from noise.

Broader Impacts. The main broader impacts proposed in the original project were centered around mentoring. Over the term of the grant (2014–19), the PI graduated his first 5 PhD students. Three of them went onto research-oriented postdoctoral positions, one got a job as a data scientist an an insurance firm, and one went straight into a teaching-oriented tenure-track faculty position. This award made it possible for them to have semesters or summers of research fellowship, and also to travel to conferences. During this time, the PI also mentored 4 postdoctoral researchers. (None of these postdocs were directly supported by this project, but 3 were supported in part by other NSF projects.)

During this time, the PI also organized a number of conferences and workshops, including some workshops that were aimed at early-career researchers. One highlight was the "Topology in Motion" thematic semester at ICERM in Fall 2016. All of the PI's graduate students and postdocs at the time were able to participate in this program with extended visits.
